# NBA Finals

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

NBA Finals  
---  
[![The NBA Finals
logo.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/The_NBA_Finals_logo.svg/220px-
The_NBA_Finals_logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:The_NBA_Finals_logo.svg)  
Status | Active  
Genre | Sporting event  
Date(s) | June  
Frequency | Annual  
Country | ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png) [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")  
Inaugurated | 1947 (1947)  
  
The **NBA Finals** is the championship series of the [National Basketball
Association](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association "National Basketball
Association") (NBA). The entrants are determined by the victors of the
[Eastern](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference \(NBA\)") and
[Western](/wiki/Western_Conference_\(NBA\) "Western Conference \(NBA\)")
conferences, who engage in a [best-of-seven](/wiki/Playoff_format#Best-of-
seven_playoff "Playoff format") game series to determine the league champion.
The winners of the Finals are awarded the [Larry O'Brien Championship
Trophy](/wiki/Larry_O%27Brien_Championship_Trophy "Larry O'Brien Championship
Trophy"), which replaced the [Walter A. Brown
Trophy](/wiki/Walter_A._Brown_Trophy "Walter A. Brown Trophy") in 1983.

Prior to the 1949-50 season, the series was named the BAA Finals, before
seeing alteration following the merger between the [Basketball Association of
America](/wiki/Basketball_Association_of_America "Basketball Association of
America") (BAA) and the [National Basketball
League](/wiki/National_Basketball_League_\(United_States\) "National
Basketball League \(United States\)") (NBL) which created the modern NBA. The
competition oversaw further name changes to NBA World Championship Series from
1950 to 1982, as well as a brief stint as the Showdown, before settling on NBA
Finals in 1986.[1]

The NBA Finals was initially structured to harbor a 2–3–2 format until 2013,
where the first two and last two games of the series were played at the arena
of the team who earned [home-court advantage](/wiki/Home_advantage "Home
advantage") by having the better record during the regular season. This was
then altered, because teams with the home-court advantage went 21–8 in all
Finals appearances. The competition is currently structured under a 2–2–1–1–1
format, where the first two games are played at home for the higher-seeded
team, and the following two at the home of the lower-seeded team. The
following three are played at each team's home arena respectively.[2]

A total of 19 franchises have won the NBA Finals. The [Boston
Celtics](/wiki/Boston_Celtics "Boston Celtics") hold the record for the most
victories, having won the competition 17 times, as well as winning the
competition the most times in a row, winning it eight times from 1959 to 1966.
The [Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") have
been runners-up the most times, winning 16 finals. The Eastern Conference has
provided the most champions, with 38 wins from ten franchises, while the
Western Conference have 32, from nine franchises.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

See also: [List of NBA champions](/wiki/List_of_NBA_champions "List of NBA
champions")

### 1947–56: Beginnings and Lakers
dynasty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: 1947–56: Beginnings and Lakers dynasty")]

During the first decade of the NBA, the [Minneapolis
Lakers](/wiki/Minneapolis_Lakers "Minneapolis Lakers") had the first NBA
dynasty, winning five championships in six years under [Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Hall_of_Fame "Hall of Fame") head coach [John
Kundla](/wiki/John_Kundla "John Kundla"). The team also featured [George
Mikan](/wiki/George_Mikan "George Mikan"), one of the greatest players in NBA
history.

### 1957–69: Celtics
dynasty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 1957–69: Celtics dynasty")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell.jpg/200px-
Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell.jpg)](/wiki/File:Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Wilt_Chamberlain_Bill_Russell.jpg "Enlarge")

[Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell") (off ball) was a member of
one of the first dynasties in the NBA, winning eight straight titles while
contending against [Wilt Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt
Chamberlain") (on ball).

The [Boston Celtics](/wiki/Boston_Celtics "Boston Celtics") went 11–1 in the
NBA Finals during 13 seasons (1956–57 to 1968–69). They won eight straight NBA
championships from 1959 through 1966.[3] This period marks the largest stretch
of seasons that a single team made up over 65% of Finals appearances, and also
includes the [only ever time](/wiki/1957_NBA_Finals "1957 NBA Finals") the NBA
Finals was decided in double overtime.

With the establishment of the Celtics dynasty in 1957 spearheaded by center
[Bill Russell](/wiki/Bill_Russell "Bill Russell"), the team would see great
success, only ever encountering difficulty when up against teams led by [Wilt
Chamberlain](/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain "Wilt Chamberlain"). However, for most of
the late 1950s and 1960s, the Celtics and Russell managed to have an upper
hand on teams led by Chamberlain.

In 1964, Chamberlain, who had moved to the state of California alongside [his
team](/wiki/Philadelphia_Warriors "Philadelphia Warriors"), led the [San
Francisco Warriors](/wiki/San_Francisco_Warriors "San Francisco Warriors") to
a Western Conference championship, but again failed to conquer the Celtics.
The following season, he returned to the [Eastern
Conference](/wiki/Eastern_Conference_\(NBA\) "Eastern Conference \(NBA\)") to
join the [Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers"),
who were the former Syracuse Nationals that had relocated to the city to cover
the vacancy created with the departure of the Warriors.

The first clash between the two stars in the playoffs was in 1966, with Boston
winning the series 4–1. In the following season, Philadelphia coach [Alex
Hannum](/wiki/Alex_Hannum "Alex Hannum") instructed Chamberlain to provide an
increased focus on playing a team game, to avoid drawing the double-teams that
troubled Chamberlain during the Finals. This tactical change brought the team
to a new record of 68 wins the following season, as well as defeating the
Celtics before winning the Finals. In 1968, Boston overcame a 3–1 deficit
against Philadelphia to once again arrive in the Finals. They went on to
defeat the [Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers")
in the Finals to again become NBA Champions.

In 1969, the Celtics faced great difficulty entering the postseason, as they
had an aging team and multiple injuries to a number of players. They qualified
for the playoffs as the fourth and final seed in the East, while the Lakers,
who in the added Chamberlain in the offseason to join stars [Jerry
West](/wiki/Jerry_West "Jerry West") and [Elgin Baylor](/wiki/Elgin_Baylor
"Elgin Baylor"). The Lakers won the West and were prohibitive favorites to
become Champions for the first time since relocating to Los Angeles. Despite
holding a 2-1 advantage going into Game 4, the Lakers led 87–86 and had the
ball with 10 seconds to play. But after a turnover, [Sam
Jones](/wiki/Sam_Jones_\(basketball\) "Sam Jones \(basketball\)") scored to
give the Celtics a narrow 88–87 win and tying the series. The series was
eventually tied 3-3 going into Game 7 in Los Angeles, with Lakers owner [Jack
Cooke](/wiki/Jack_Kent_Cooke "Jack Kent Cooke") hanging balloons in the arena
in anticipation of a Lakers victory. West also picked up injuries to his thigh
and hamstring during the series, however, returned to play for the final game.
Russell utilized this newly lacking mobility in West to organize fast breaks
at every opportunity for the Celtics, which allowed them to gain an early
lead. They held off a furious Lakers comeback to win 108–106 and win the
series, and win their eleventh championship in 13 years.

As many stars either declined or retired following this win, it is largely
recognized as the last NBA Finals conducted by the Celtics dynasty.

### 1970–79: Decade of
parity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: 1970–79: Decade of parity")]

The 1970s saw eight different teams win the title, with the Celtics and [New
York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks") winning twice.

In [1970](/wiki/1970_NBA_Finals "1970 NBA Finals"), a classic final featured
the Knicks against the Lakers. In the waning moments of Game 3, with the
series tied, [Jerry West](/wiki/Jerry_West "Jerry West") hit a basket from 60
feet to tie the game, a shot which became one of the most famous ever.
However, the Knicks won in [overtime](/wiki/Overtime_\(sports\) "Overtime
\(sports\)") and continued their momentum for a 4–3 win, becoming the first
team after the Celtics dynasty to win an NBA championship. The [Milwaukee
Bucks](/wiki/Milwaukee_Bucks "Milwaukee Bucks") also won their first franchise
title, defeating the [Baltimore
Bullets](/wiki/Baltimore_Bullets_\(1963%E2%80%9373\) "Baltimore Bullets
\(1963–73\)") in 1971.

Two seasons after losing in the Finals, the Lakers got a measure of revenge by
winning 33 straight games, the longest such streak in NBA history. By season's
end, they broke the record for most wins in a season with 69, one more than
the [1966–67 Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/1966-67_Philadelphia_76ers_season
"1966-67 Philadelphia 76ers season"), before taking home the
[championship](/wiki/1972_NBA_Finals "1972 NBA Finals") for the first time
since relocating to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"). The Knicks
returned to win the championship again a season later to record their second
ever victorious season.

Despite the rise of the Knicks, the [1974 championship](/wiki/1974_NBA_Finals
"1974 NBA Finals") returned to the Celtics, as a newly formed cohort of
players led by [Dave Cowens](/wiki/Dave_Cowens "Dave Cowens") demonstrated
excellent teamwork and resilience to win in seven games to secure another
title.

Following the success of the Lakers, the 1970s were characterized by a major
breakthrough of the league's western franchises. In 1975, after compiling a
48–34 regular-season record, the [Golden State
Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State Warriors") swept the
heavily favored [Washington Bullets](/wiki/Washington_Bullets "Washington
Bullets") 4–0 in the [1975 NBA Finals](/wiki/1975_NBA_Finals "1975 NBA
Finals"). In 1976, the [Phoenix Suns](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns"), who
only enjoyed eight years of existence as a franchise, overcame a losing record
early in the season to build a remarkable win streak to finish 42–40. The
events culminated in upset victories over the [Seattle
SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics") and the
Warriors, before facing Boston in the Finals. The teams split the first four
games, before Game 5 went into three overtimes before Boston won 128–126. The
Celtics managed to secure their 13th championship quickly after, defeating the
Suns 87–80 in Game 6.

Other western franchises that secured their first titles in the 1970s included
the [Portland Trail Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail
Blazers") in 1977, and the Washington Bullets defeating the SuperSonics in
1978. The SuperSonics managed to exact revenge in the following season,
however, as they secured their first franchise title in 1979.

### 1980–90: Lakers–Celtics rivalry and the Bad
Boys[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
1980–90: Lakers–Celtics rivalry and the Bad Boys")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/1985_Finals_Lipofsky.jpg)](/wiki/File:1985_Finals_Lipofsky.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1985_Finals_Lipofsky.jpg "Enlarge")

The 1980s saw a renewal in the rivalry between the [Boston
Celtics](/wiki/Boston_Celtics "Boston Celtics") (green) and the [Los Angeles
Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") (gold), combining to
win eight titles.

Between 1980 and 1990, the Celtics, 76ers, Lakers, or the [Detroit
Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons") won every NBA
Finals.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] The Lakers won five titles from 1980 to 1990 (1980, 1982, 1985,
1987, and 1988); the Celtics won three (1981, 1984, and 1986); the Pistons won
twice (1989 and 1990); and the 76ers won once (1983).

The [1979 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship
Game](/wiki/1979_NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship_Game "1979
NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship Game") featured [Magic
Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson")'s [Michigan State
University](/wiki/Michigan_State_University "Michigan State University") team
facing off against [Larry Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird "Larry Bird")'s [Indiana
State University](/wiki/Indiana_State_University "Indiana State University")
team. This meeting has been immortalized as the beginning of the Lakers and
Celtics rivalry of the 1980s, which saw each team being represented by either
player respectively. The game also attracted the largest ever TV rating for an
NCAA Championship game, with 38 percent of all television viewers that night
tuned to the game.

Bird had actually been drafted the year before, but later decided to stay an
additional year, and the two superstars both entered the league in 1979,
leading their respective teams to dazzling heights. Johnson and the [Showtime
Lakers](/wiki/Showtime_Lakers "Showtime Lakers") reached the [1980 NBA
Finals](/wiki/1980_NBA_Finals "1980 NBA Finals") against the 76ers, which was
also led by NBA superstar [Julius Erving](/wiki/Julius_Erving "Julius
Erving"). The Lakers took a 3–2 lead, but [Kareem Abdul-
Jabbar](/wiki/Kareem_Abdul-Jabbar "Kareem Abdul-Jabbar") could not play in
Game 6 due to injury. Johnson, a natural point guard, was shifted to center,
and ended up playing every position on the court during the game, scoring 42
points, while also attaining 15 rebounds and 7 assists[4] to win his first
championship while being awarded his first NBA Finals MVP; a remarkable
performance in the annals of the sport.

Boston reached the [1981 NBA Finals](/wiki/1981_NBA_Finals "1981 NBA Finals")
led by the "Big Three" of Larry Bird, [Kevin
McHale](/wiki/Kevin_McHale_\(basketball\) "Kevin McHale \(basketball\)"), and
[Robert Parish](/wiki/Robert_Parish "Robert Parish"). During the [1980 NBA
draft](/wiki/1980_NBA_draft "1980 NBA draft"), the Celtics traded two first
round picks to the Warriors for Parish and a first round pick later spent on
McHale. Considered to be one of the best front courts of all time, all three
players would later make the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.[5]
They met the [Houston Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets") in the
1981 Finals, practically single-handedly carried by [Moses
Malone](/wiki/Moses_Malone "Moses Malone"), who upset the Lakers and Johnson
in the first round. The Rockets were only the second team in NBA history to
make the Finals after posting a losing record in the regular season, and the
Celtics had an NBA best record of 62–20. The Celtics would later win the
Finals in 6 games.

The Lakers returned to the NBA Finals in [1982](/wiki/1982_NBA_Finals "1982
NBA Finals"), time time led by new coach [Pat Riley](/wiki/Pat_Riley "Pat
Riley"), in a rematch against the 76ers. The 76ers defeated the Celtics in the
Eastern Conference finals in a 7-game series, but were defeated by Lakers in 6
games, with Johnson being named Finals MVP. Upon losing their past three NBA
Finals appearances, the 76ers decided that they needed one more piece to
become champions, and enlisted Malone as their premier target. On September
15, 1982, they traded for Malone, who was also the league's reigning MVP.

With the new duo of Malone and Erving, the 76ers won the [1983 NBA
Finals](/wiki/1983_NBA_Finals "1983 NBA Finals"), losing only once in the
entire playoffs, as well as sweeping the Lakers. However, the [1984 NBA
Finals](/wiki/1984_NBA_Finals "1984 NBA Finals") was conducted by the Celtics
and Lakers, who faced each other for the first time since 1969. After an
inspired performance from Bird, the Celtics toppled the Lakers 4–3. The final
game of this series attracted the largest ever TV audience for an NBA game,
and the second-largest ever for a basketball game, with only the game between
the two stars played five years earlier having a larger audience. It was the
last NBA Finals played in the 2–2–1–1–1 format, until 2014.

In the [1985 NBA Finals](/wiki/1985_NBA_Finals "1985 NBA Finals"), the Lakers
made amends for their previous eight losses to the Celtics by defeating them
in six games. Even though the Lakers lost the first game by 34 points in the
[Memorial Day Massacre](/wiki/Memorial_Day_Massacre "Memorial Day Massacre"),
they won 4 of the next 5 games, including Game 6 at the [Boston
Garden](/wiki/Boston_Garden "Boston Garden"), to finally end the long years of
frustration of failing to defeat the Celtics. These finals were the first to
be played in the 2–3–2 format, which was suggested by Boston coach [Red
Auerbach](/wiki/Red_Auerbach "Red Auerbach") to NBA commissioner [David
Stern](/wiki/David_Stern "David Stern"), as he hoped to cut back on the
frequent traveling from [Boston](/wiki/Boston "Boston") to Los Angeles.

The [1986 NBA Finals](/wiki/1986_NBA_Finals "1986 NBA Finals") saw the Celtics
face off against the Rockets, with Boston winning in six games, as well as
securing their 16th title. Bird was also named Finals MVP for the second time.
In [1987](/wiki/1987_NBA_Finals "1987 NBA Finals"), the Lakers and Celtics met
again, with both sides holding a win in the Finals apiece. With the third
being contested, it is regarded as a rubber match between the two dynasties.
The Lakers won the first two games, but Boston won Game 3. In Game 4, Johnson
hit an sky-hook with two seconds left to give the Lakers a 107–106 win and a
3–1 series lead. The Lakers would lose Game 5, but would eventually win Game 6
to clinch the series, and a 2-1 all time win against the Celtics. Johnson was
also named Finals MVP for the third time.

In the following two seasons, the aging Celtics failed to reach the Finals,
becoming overshadowed by the rise of the [Detroit
Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons"). The Lakers would manage to
defend their title in the [1988 Finals](/wiki/1988_NBA_Finals "1988 NBA
Finals"), winning the series in 7 games against the Pistons. They then became
the first team to win back-to-back NBA titles since 1969.[6] Seeking a three-
peat in [1989](/wiki/1989_NBA_Finals "1989 NBA Finals"), the Lakers were swept
by the Pistons in a rematch of the previous year's Finals. In
[1990](/wiki/1990_NBA_Finals "1990 NBA Finals"), the Pistons then went back-
to-back after defeating the Blazers in five games, attaining the nickname "Bad
Boys" due to its rough, physical play. Led by a Hall of Fame back court in
[Joe Dumars](/wiki/Joe_Dumars "Joe Dumars") and [Isiah
Thomas](/wiki/Isiah_Thomas "Isiah Thomas") and a rugged front court in [Dennis
Rodman](/wiki/Dennis_Rodman "Dennis Rodman") and [Bill
Laimbeer](/wiki/Bill_Laimbeer "Bill Laimbeer"), the Pistons were attained
great success.

### 1991–98: Bulls
dynasty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 1991–98: Bulls dynasty")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Phil_Jackson_Lipofsky.JPG/170px-
Phil_Jackson_Lipofsky.JPG)](/wiki/File:Phil_Jackson_Lipofsky.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Phil_Jackson_Lipofsky.JPG "Enlarge")

[Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan") combined with coach
[Phil Jackson](/wiki/Phil_Jackson "Phil Jackson") to win six NBA
championships.

The majority of the 1990s was marked by the supremacy of the [Chicago
Bulls](/wiki/Chicago_Bulls "Chicago Bulls"), which saw them appear in six
Finals. Coached by [Phil Jackson](/wiki/Phil_Jackson "Phil Jackson") and led
by NBA superstar [Michael Jordan](/wiki/Michael_Jordan "Michael Jordan"), the
Bulls won a title in every single appearance to the Finals from 1991 to 1998.
Jordan was also the Finals MVP every time. The only other team to win
championships during this period was the [Houston
Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets"), who went back-to-back in
1994 and 1995 during Jordan's initial retirement from professional basketball.

The first championship came at the expense of the [Los Angeles
Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers"), which also saw the
last appearance in the Finals for [Magic Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic
Johnson"). Billed[_[by
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] as a showdown between the aging
Johnson and the upstart Jordan, the Lakers won the first game, 93–91. For the
rest of the series, Pippen guarded Johnson, allowing Jordan to attain a free
scoring role to lead Chicago to ultimately taking the next four games. The
Bulls returned to the Finals in the next year, pitted against [Clyde
Drexler](/wiki/Clyde_Drexler "Clyde Drexler") and the [Portland Trail
Blazers](/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail Blazers"). Throughout
the 1991–1992 season, Jordan and Drexler led their teams to the best records
in their respective conferences, leading to several comparisons between the
two players in anticipation of a postseason match-up. Chicago defeated the
Trail Blazers in Game 1 by 33 points, a game notable for Jordan breaking the
record for the most three-pointer in a first half, with six. Game 2 went into
overtime, with the Trail Blazers outscoring the Bulls 18–7 in the final period
to run away with the win. Game 3 and 4 were split between Chicago and
Portland, respectively, but the Bulls took the final two games, clinching
their second championship.

In 1993, Jordan was matched against close friend [Charles
Barkley](/wiki/Charles_Barkley "Charles Barkley"), who was the league's
reigning MVP at the [Phoenix Suns](/wiki/Phoenix_Suns "Phoenix Suns"). The
Bulls won the first two games in Phoenix, with 100–92 and 111–108 as the final
scores, respectively. The Suns, rallying behind Barkley, won Game 3, 129–121,
in Chicago in triple overtime. The Bulls took Game 4, 111–105, with Jordan
scoring 55 points and tying [Rick Barry](/wiki/Rick_Barry "Rick Barry") for
the second-most points in an NBA Finals game. The Suns won Game 5, 108–98,
sending the series back to Phoenix. Chicago won the series clincher in Game 6,
99–98,on [John Paxson](/wiki/John_Paxson "John Paxson")'s three-pointer, as
the Bulls became the third team in history to [three-peat](/wiki/Three-peat
"Three-peat"). After this win, Jordan would retire from basketball to pursue a
career in baseball.

Following Jordan's departure, the [Houston Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets
"Houston Rockets"), led by [Hakeem Olajuwon](/wiki/Hakeem_Olajuwon "Hakeem
Olajuwon"), won the 1994 and 1995 NBA titles. During this period, Olajuwon
became the only player in history to win the [NBA
MVP](/wiki/National_Basketball_Association_Most_Valuable_Player_Award
"National Basketball Association Most Valuable Player Award"), [NBA Defensive
Player of the Year](/wiki/NBA_Defensive_Player_of_the_Year_Award "NBA
Defensive Player of the Year Award") and Finals MVP awards in the same season.
That was the only year that both the NBA and [NHL
finals](/wiki/Stanley_Cup_Finals "Stanley Cup Finals") went to seven games
while involving teams from the same city, with the Rockets facing the [New
York Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks") in 1994. With their win
in Game 7, the Rockets denied New York from winning both the NBA and NHL
titles in the same year, as the [New York Rangers](/wiki/New_York_Rangers "New
York Rangers") won the [1994 Stanley Cup Finals](/wiki/1994_Stanley_Cup_Finals
"1994 Stanley Cup Finals"). After trading for Drexler midseason, the Rockets
later swept an [Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando Magic") team
consisting of [Shaquille O'Neal](/wiki/Shaquille_O%27Neal "Shaquille O'Neal")
and [Penny Hardaway](/wiki/Penny_Hardaway "Penny Hardaway") in the 1995
Finals; Olajuwon was again named Finals MVP, and the Rockets became the fifth
franchise to win back-to-back titles and became the first 6th-seeded team to
win the title without enjoying home court advantage on any of their playoff
series.

After his short stint in baseball, Jordan returned to basketball late in the
1994–95 season. Although he did not lead the Bulls to the Finals, he returned
to pre-retirement form the next year while the team acquired perennial
rebounding champion [Dennis Rodman](/wiki/Dennis_Rodman "Dennis Rodman"). The
[1995–96 Bulls](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_Chicago_Bulls_season "1995–96 Chicago
Bulls season") finished the regular season 72–10, attaining, at the time, the
best regular season record in NBA history (Later surpassed by the Golden State
Warriors in the 2015-16 season with a record of 73-9). They dominated in the
playoffs, with series records of 3–0, 4–1 and 4–0, before facing the [Seattle
SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics") in the NBA
Finals. After the Bulls took a 3–0 series lead, Seattle won the next two games
after coach [George Karl](/wiki/George_Karl "George Karl") switched point
guard [Gary Payton](/wiki/Gary_Payton "Gary Payton") onto Jordan, leading to a
sixth game. However, Jordan altered his game to accommodate the advances of
Payton, and the Bulls won Game 6 to win their fourth title.

In 1997 and 1998, the Bulls met the [Utah Jazz](/wiki/Utah_Jazz "Utah Jazz")
in the Finals twice. Led by [Olympians](/wiki/Dream_Team_\(basketball\) "Dream
Team \(basketball\)") [John Stockton](/wiki/John_Stockton "John Stockton") and
[Karl Malone](/wiki/Karl_Malone "Karl Malone"), the Jazz were defeated in both
Finals by the Bulls in six games. In both series, Chicago won by hitting
winning shots in the sixth and deciding game — the first by [Steve
Kerr](/wiki/Steve_Kerr "Steve Kerr") in 1997 in Chicago, and the second by
Jordan in Utah in 1998. This saw Chicago winning their sixth NBA championship,
and managing their second three-peat. However, prior to the 1999 season,
Jackson decided to retire, which set off a chain reaction that resulted in
most of the team, including Jordan and Pippen, requesting to leave the Bulls.
With no foundation of youth to build upon, the Bulls became a [lottery-
bound](/wiki/NBA_Draft_Lottery "NBA Draft Lottery") team for the next six
seasons.

### 1999–2010: Lakers' and Spurs'
dominance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: 1999–2010: Lakers' and Spurs' dominance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Kobe_Bryant_8.jpg/220px-
Kobe_Bryant_8.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kobe_Bryant_8.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kobe_Bryant_8.jpg "Enlarge")

[Kobe Bryant](/wiki/Kobe_Bryant "Kobe Bryant") was a member of the [Los
Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") that won five
NBA championships from 2000-2010.

The [Los Angeles Lakers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers "Los Angeles Lakers") and
[San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs") combined to
win nine NBA Championships during this period.

The Spurs were responsible for winning four championships during this period,
in 1999, 2003, 2005, and 2007. In the 1999 NBA Playoffs, the Spurs finished
with a 15–2 mark, including sweeps of the Blazers and Lakers. With a defensive
squad led by [David Robinson](/wiki/David_Robinson_\(basketball\) "David
Robinson \(basketball\)") and [Tim Duncan](/wiki/Tim_Duncan "Tim Duncan"), San
Antonio's 84.7 points allowed per game was the fewest average points allowed
in the post-season in the last 30 years. In the [Finals](/wiki/1999_NBA_Finals
"1999 NBA Finals") that year, the Spurs held the [New York
Knicks](/wiki/New_York_Knicks "New York Knicks"), the first #8 seed team to
reach the finals in NBA history, to an average of 79.8 points per game. During
the [2003 NBA Finals](/wiki/2003_NBA_Finals "2003 NBA Finals"), the Spurs
defeated the Nets in 6 games, which also marked the first championship
contested between two former ABA teams. In Game 6, Duncan was two blocks short
of recording the first [quadruple-double](/wiki/Quadruple-double "Quadruple-
double") in NBA Finals history, finishing with 21 points, 20 rebounds, 10
assists, and 8 blocks. The Spurs went on to defeat the [Detroit
Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons "Detroit Pistons") 4–3 in the [2005 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2005_NBA_Finals "2005 NBA Finals"), as well as sweeping the
[LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James")-led [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") in the [2007 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2007_NBA_Finals "2007 NBA Finals"). Duncan won the Finals MVP in
1999, 2003 and 2005. In 2007, [Tony Parker](/wiki/Tony_Parker "Tony Parker")
was named MVP, becoming the first European-born player to win the award.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Tim_Duncan.jpg/170px-
Tim_Duncan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tim_Duncan.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tim_Duncan.jpg "Enlarge")

[Tim Duncan](/wiki/Tim_Duncan "Tim Duncan") won five championships with the
[San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs") from
1999-2014.

From 2000 to 2002, the Lakers, led by [Shaquille
O'Neal](/wiki/Shaquille_O%27Neal "Shaquille O'Neal") and [Kobe
Bryant](/wiki/Kobe_Bryant "Kobe Bryant"), won three straight NBA
Championships. O'Neal won the finals MVP all three times. Their [first
championship](/wiki/2000_NBA_Finals "2000 NBA Finals") came at the expense of
the [Indiana Pacers](/wiki/Indiana_Pacers "Indiana Pacers"), whom the Lakers
defeated in 6 games. During their [2001](/wiki/2001_NBA_Finals "2001 NBA
Finals") postseason run, the Lakers swept their first 3 series and won the
Finals in 5 games, finishing with an unprecedented 15–1 record, the best
postseason record in NBA history. Their opponent in the Finals that year were
the [Philadelphia 76ers](/wiki/Philadelphia_76ers "Philadelphia 76ers"), led
by [Allen Iverson](/wiki/Allen_Iverson "Allen Iverson"). In the [2002 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2002_NBA_Finals "2002 NBA Finals"), the Lakers swept the [New
Jersey Nets](/wiki/New_Jersey_Nets "New Jersey Nets"), leading almost the
entire time in each game; only for a short while after the beginning of Game 4
did the [New Jersey Nets](/wiki/New_Jersey_Nets "New Jersey Nets") gain any
significant lead in any game.

In the 2003 offseason, veteran stars [Gary Payton](/wiki/Gary_Payton "Gary
Payton") and [Karl Malone](/wiki/Karl_Malone "Karl Malone") signed with the
Lakers. Along with Bryant and O'Neal, they formed what many expected to be one
of the best teams in NBA history, and were the favorites to win the
championship in 2004. However, the [Detroit Pistons](/wiki/Detroit_Pistons
"Detroit Pistons"), under coach [Larry Brown](/wiki/Larry_Brown_\(basketball\)
"Larry Brown \(basketball\)"), upset the Lakers in 5 games. [Chauncey
Billups](/wiki/Chauncey_Billups "Chauncey Billups") was named the Finals MVP.
Now established as one of the premier powerhouses of the East, the Pistons
would return to the NBA Finals in the following year, bowing out to the Spurs
in seven games.

The [2006 NBA Finals](/wiki/2006_NBA_Finals "2006 NBA Finals") were the only
Finals during this period not to feature the Spurs or Lakers, instead
featuring the [Miami Heat](/wiki/Miami_Heat "Miami Heat") and [Dallas
Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks"). It was the first NBA
Finals since 1971 that had both Western and Eastern Conference champions
making their first Finals appearance in franchise history. The Mavericks won
the first two games at home, but the turning point of the series was in Game
3, when the Heat overcame a 13-point deficit with less than 6 minutes left in
the fourth quarter to win 98–96. The comeback was led by [Dwyane
Wade](/wiki/Dwyane_Wade "Dwyane Wade")'s 12 points in the final six minutes
and a clutch outside jumpshot by [Gary Payton](/wiki/Gary_Payton "Gary
Payton"), who was appearing in his third NBA finals. Miami swept all three of
their home games, two of which were sparked by fourth quarter comebacks led by
Wade; the Heat would win their first ever championship in game six.

The Lakers returned to the finals in 2008, against the [Boston
Celtics](/wiki/Boston_Celtics "Boston Celtics"). Renewing the teams' fierce
rivalry, this marked the 11th time that these two teams met in the Finals, the
last such meeting happening in 1987. The Celtics, who defeated the Lakers 4–2,
were led by their "Big Three" superstars of [Ray Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray
Allen"), [Kevin Garnett](/wiki/Kevin_Garnett "Kevin Garnett"), and [Paul
Pierce](/wiki/Paul_Pierce "Paul Pierce"), who was also named Finals MVP.

The Lakers bounced back from their 2008 loss and returned to the Finals in
2009, where they faced the [Orlando Magic](/wiki/Orlando_Magic "Orlando
Magic"), led by [Defensive Player of the
Year](/wiki/NBA_Defensive_Player_of_the_Year_Award "NBA Defensive Player of
the Year Award") [Dwight Howard](/wiki/Dwight_Howard "Dwight Howard") in 2009.
The Lakers would defeat Orlando in five games, with Bryant earning the Finals
MVP award. The Lakers met the Celtics once again in
[2010](/wiki/2010_NBA_Finals "2010 NBA Finals"), trailing 3–2 before winning
the last two at home, marking the first time in the history of the Celtics
that they lost a Game 7 in the NBA Finals. Bryant was also named Finals MVP,
with the triumphs in 2009 and 2010 becoming [Phil Jackson](/wiki/Phil_Jackson
"Phil Jackson")'s 10th and 11th NBA titles. With these championship victories,
Jackson surpassed both [Red Auerbach](/wiki/Red_Auerbach "Red Auerbach")'s
record for most NBA titles of all time and [National Hockey
League](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") coach [Scotty
Bowman](/wiki/Scotty_Bowman "Scotty Bowman")'s record for most titles as head
coach in any major American professional sport.

### 2011–14: Rise of the
Heat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section:
2011–14: Rise of the Heat")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/LeBron_James_vs_Washington_3-30-11.jpg/129px-
LeBron_James_vs_Washington_3-30-11.jpg)](/wiki/File:LeBron_James_vs_Washington_3-30-11.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Dwyane_Wade_e1.jpg/165px-
Dwyane_Wade_e1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dwyane_Wade_e1.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Chris_Bosh_e1.jpg/111px-
Chris_Bosh_e1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chris_Bosh_e1.jpg)

[LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") (left) joined [Dwyane
Wade](/wiki/Dwyane_Wade "Dwyane Wade") (center) and [Chris
Bosh](/wiki/Chris_Bosh "Chris Bosh") (right) at the [Miami
Heat](/wiki/Miami_Heat "Miami Heat") to form the [Big
Three](/wiki/Big_Three_\(Miami_Heat\) "Big Three \(Miami Heat\)").

During the 2010 offseason, the [Miami Heat](/wiki/Miami_Heat "Miami Heat") re-
signed team captain [Dwyane Wade](/wiki/Dwyane_Wade "Dwyane Wade") and added
free agents [Chris Bosh](/wiki/Chris_Bosh "Chris Bosh") and [LeBron
James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James") to form the [Big
Three](/wiki/Big_Three_\(Miami_Heat\) "Big Three \(Miami Heat\)").[7] The Heat
were then considered the favorites by many to win multiple championships,
appearing in the next four finals, and winning two, in
[2012](/wiki/2012_NBA_Finals "2012 NBA Finals") and
[2013](/wiki/2013_NBA_Finals "2013 NBA Finals"). James has also later
represented the Eastern Conference in the NBA Finals in every year since 2011.

The second appearance by the Heat in a Finals came in
[2011](/wiki/2011_NBA_Finals "2011 NBA Finals"), where they were pitted
against the [Dallas Mavericks](/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks "Dallas Mavericks") in a
rematch of the finals from [five years earlier](/wiki/2006_NBA_Finals "2006
NBA Finals"). The Mavericks, who were led by [Dirk
Nowitzki](/wiki/Dirk_Nowitzki "Dirk Nowitzki"), [Jason
Terry](/wiki/Jason_Terry "Jason Terry"), [Tyson Chandler](/wiki/Tyson_Chandler
"Tyson Chandler"), and [Jason Kidd](/wiki/Jason_Kidd "Jason Kidd"), won the
series 4–2, with Nowitzki being named the Finals MVP. The Heat returned to the
finals in the [following year](/wiki/2012_NBA_Finals "2012 NBA Finals")
against the young upstart [Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder
"Oklahoma City Thunder") team, in a series that pitted reigning league MVP
James and 3-time [NBA scoring
leader](/wiki/List_of_National_Basketball_Association_annual_scoring_leaders
"List of National Basketball Association annual scoring leaders") [Kevin
Durant](/wiki/Kevin_Durant "Kevin Durant") against each other, neither of whom
had won a championship at the time. After the Thunder took Game 1 at home, the
Heat won four straight games to win the series 4–1 becoming the first team to
win a championship after trailing in three different series. Winning his first
championship, James was unanimously named NBA Finals MVP.

The Heat repeated as champions in 2013, this time over the [San Antonio
Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San Antonio Spurs"), with the finals being the
first since 1987 to feature four former Finals MVPs in a Finals; with [Tim
Duncan](/wiki/Tim_Duncan "Tim Duncan") (1999, 2003, 2005) and [Tony
Parker](/wiki/Tony_Parker "Tony Parker") (2007) for the Spurs, and Wade (2006)
and James (2012) for the Heat. The Spurs were up 3–2 in the series going into
Game 6 in Miami. With seconds remaining in regulation, [Ray
Allen](/wiki/Ray_Allen "Ray Allen") scored a game-tying three-pointer to send
the game into overtime, and the Heat would prevail 103–100. The game is
considered by some to have been one of the greatest playoff games in NBA
history.[8] The Heat would win Game 7, 95–88, to clinch the title. James was
again named the Finals MVP for the second straight year.

Looking for a [3-peat](/wiki/3-peat "3-peat"), the Heat dominated the [2014
postseason](/wiki/2014_NBA_Playoffs "2014 NBA Playoffs"), going 12–3 in the
first three rounds. They reached the [2014 NBA Finals](/wiki/2014_NBA_Finals
"2014 NBA Finals") and faced the Spurs in a rematch of the [2013
Finals](/wiki/2013_NBA_Finals "2013 NBA Finals"). With James limited in Game 1
due to leg cramps, the Spurs ended the game on a 31–9 run, winning the game
110–95. The Heat would win Game 2, but that would be their only win of the
series, as the Spurs would win Games 3, 4, and 5 to win the Championship,
their first since 2007 and the fifth and final title of Duncan's career.
[Kawhi Leonard](/wiki/Kawhi_Leonard "Kawhi Leonard") was named Finals MVP,
becoming the third-youngest Finals MVP after Duncan and [Magic
Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson").

### 2015–present: Cavaliers–Warriors
rivalry[[edit](/w/index.php?title=NBA_Finals&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 2015–present: Cavaliers–Warriors rivalry")]

The rivalry between these two teams began when they faced each other in the
[2015 NBA Finals](/wiki/2015_NBA_Finals "2015 NBA Finals").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Stephen_Curry_dribbling_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg/150px-
Stephen_Curry_dribbling_2016_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stephen_Curry_dribbling_2016_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stephen_Curry_dribbling_2016_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

[Stephen Curry](/wiki/Stephen_Curry "Stephen Curry") led the [Golden State
Warriors](/wiki/Golden_State_Warriors "Golden State Warriors") to the best
regular season record in NBA history, and the [2015](/wiki/2015_NBA_Finals
"2015 NBA Finals") and [2017](/wiki/2017_NBA_Finals "2017 NBA Finals")
championship.

After the 2014 Finals, [LeBron James](/wiki/LeBron_James "LeBron James")
became a free agent and returned to the [Cleveland
Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers") where he teamed up
with [Kyrie Irving](/wiki/Kyrie_Irving "Kyrie Irving"). The Cavs also traded
for [Kevin Love](/wiki/Kevin_Love "Kevin Love") to form a new _[Big
Three](/wiki/Big_Three_\(Cleveland_Cavaliers\) "Big Three \(Cleveland
Cavaliers\)")_ in Cleveland as they led the Cavs to the [2015 NBA
Finals](/wiki/2015_NBA_Finals "2015 NBA Finals"). In the [2015
postseason](/wiki/2015_NBA_Playoffs "2015 NBA Playoffs"), 2014 finalist Miami
Heat did not qualify in the playoffs after losing James to free agency and due
to mediocrity stemming from brutal injuries all season, and the former
defending champions, the [San Antonio Spurs](/wiki/San_Antonio_Spurs "San
Antonio Spurs"), were eliminated in a Game 7 battle against the [Los Angeles
Clippers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Clippers "Los Angeles Clippers") in the first
round. This allowed Cleveland to conquer the East. Golden State, spearheaded
by reigning [MVP](/wiki/NBA_MVP "NBA MVP"), [Stephen
Curry](/wiki/Stephen_Curry "Stephen Curry"), achieved a 67–15 record and were
able to take the West. Entering the [2015 Finals](/wiki/2015_NBA_Finals "2015
NBA Finals"), James and current Cavalier and former Heat teammate [James
Jones](/wiki/James_Jones_\(basketball_player\) "James Jones \(basketball
player\)") made their fifth straight finals appearance – the first two players
to do this since the 1960s Celtics. The Warriors managed to defy conventional
wisdom and traditionalist ideas by winning the championship with a small-ball,
three-point shooting, fast-paced team. The Warriors won Game 1 in overtime,
with the Cavaliers losing Irving to injury in the process. The Cavaliers would
win Games 2 and 3, however, the Warriors won the next three games after coach
[Steve Kerr](/wiki/Steve_Kerr "Steve Kerr") made the adjustment of inserting
sixth man [Andre Iguodala](/wiki/Andre_Iguodala "Andre Iguodala") into the
starting lineup in place of center [Andrew Bogut](/wiki/Andrew_Bogut "Andrew
Bogut"), thus achieving the desired small-ball offense. The Warriors defeated
the Cavaliers 4–2, with Iguodala becoming the first player to not start in any
regular season game to win the Finals MVP award.

During the [2015–16 season](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_NBA_season "2015–16 NBA
season"), the Warriors broke the record for most wins in a season with a
record of 73–9 and Curry would go on to win his second straight MVP award, as
well as becoming the first unanimous MVP in history and shattering his own
record for three-pointers made in a single season by over one hundred in the
process. The Warriors would advance to the NBA Finals with 3 straight wins
against a [Kevin Durant](/wiki/Kevin_Durant "Kevin Durant") led Oklahoma City
Thunder in the Western Conference Finals after trailing 3–1. The Cavaliers
finished the season as the top-seed in the Eastern Conference and defeated the
[Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors") 4–2 in the Eastern
Conference Finals to advance, facing the Warriors in a rematch of last year's
matchup. In the [2016 NBA Finals](/wiki/2016_NBA_Finals "2016 NBA Finals"),
James led the Cavaliers to their first-ever NBA championship in franchise
history, recovering from a 3–1 deficit to win 4–3. During the final three
minutes of Game 7 with the score tied at 89, Irving missed a tightly contested
lay-up, allowing Iguodala to secure the rebound and run for a fast break.
Curry passed the ball back to Iguodala for a give-and-go play, however, James
tracked back to make a [chase-down block](/wiki/The_Block_\(basketball\) "The
Block \(basketball\)") on Iguodala, keeping the scores leveled as a timeout
was called with 1:07 remaining. Irving hit a 3-point shot to take the lead
with less than one minute remaining and Love successfully defended Curry
trying to make a 3-pointer. The Cavaliers managed to hold on to the lead to
win and end the city's [52-year championship
drought](/wiki/Cleveland_sports_curse "Cleveland sports curse"), James was
named the Finals MVP.[9]

In the summer of 2016, the Warriors acquired Durant through free agency. After
finishing 67–15, they became the first team in history to win 67+ games in
three straight seasons, and also went 12–0 in the playoffs, becoming the first
team to sweep the first three rounds of the playoffs since the first round
changed to best-of-seven in 2003. Meanwhile, the Cavaliers only lost one game
in their first three series, setting up another rubber match against the
Warriors in the [2017 NBA Finals](/wiki/2017_NBA_Finals "2017 NBA Finals").
This marks the first time in history that two teams have met in three straight
NBA Finals. The Warriors eventually won the series 4–1 with Durant being named
the Finals MVP.[10] The Warriors took a 3-0 series lead while setting a
playoffs record of 15 consecutive wins before losing game 4 of the finals to
the Cavs. The Warriors closed out their playoff series with a 13.5 point
differential.[11]

Their other appearances came in the [2013–14 season](/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_NBA_season "2013–14 NBA season") when they lost to the [Oklahoma City Thunder](/wiki/Oklahoma_City_Thunder "Oklahoma City Thunder"), and in the [2014–15 season](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_NBA_season "2014–15 NBA season") when they lost to the [Houston Rockets](/wiki/Houston_Rockets "Houston Rockets").

They have played in the 1976 ABA championship, but lost to the [New York Nets](/wiki/New_York_Nets "New York Nets"), as well as participating in the 1978 conference finals, before ultimately losing to the [Seattle SuperSonics](/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics "Seattle SuperSonics"). [Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver_Grizzlies "Vancouver Grizzlies")/[Memphis Grizzlies](/wiki/Memphis_Grizzlies "Memphis Grizzlies") | 21 | [1995](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_NBA_season "1995–96 NBA season") | Reached the [Western Conference finals](/wiki/2013_NBA_Playoffs "2013 NBA Playoffs") in the [2012–13 season](/wiki/2012%E2%80%9313_NBA_season "2012–13 NBA season"), but lost to the Spurs.  
[Toronto Raptors](/wiki/Toronto_Raptors "Toronto Raptors") | 21 | [1995](/wiki/1995%E2%80%9396_NBA_season "1995–96 NBA season") | Reached the [Eastern Conference finals](/wiki/2016_NBA_Playoffs "2016 NBA Playoffs") in the [2015–16 season](/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_NBA_season "2015–16 NBA season"), but lost to the [Cleveland Cavaliers](/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers "Cleveland Cavaliers").  
[New Orleans/Oklahoma City Hornets/Pelicans](/wiki/New_Orleans_Pelicans "New Orleans Pelicans")* | 14 | [2002](/wiki/2002%E2%80%9303_NBA_season "2002–03 NBA season") | Reached the [conference semifinals](/wiki/2008_NBA_Playoffs "2008 NBA Playoffs") in the [2007–08 season](/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_NBA_season "2007–08 NBA season"), but lost to the Spurs.  
  
(*) As a result of the original franchise's relocation to [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"), the NBA team in
[Charlotte](/wiki/Charlotte,_North_Carolina "Charlotte, North Carolina")
suspended operations for the 2002–03 and the 2003–04 seasons, before a new
team, also named the Bobcats, was established for the 2004–05 season. In 2014,
the Bobcats later became the second incarnation of the Charlotte Hornets, and
retained the history and records of the Hornets organization from 1982 to
2002. The original Hornets, now renamed the Pelicans, obtained the records
during their time in New Orleans and [Oklahoma City](/wiki/Oklahoma_City
"Oklahoma City") from 2002 to 2013.
